speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Was not Count John here at supper?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I saw him not.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: him but I am heart-burned an hour after.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: He were an excellent man that were made just in the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: midway between him and Benedick: the one is too

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: like an image and says nothing, and the other too

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signior

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Benedick's face,--

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: in the world, if a' could get her good-will.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: In faith, she's too curst.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen God's

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: sending that way; for it is said, 'God sends a curst

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: cow short horns;' but to a cow too curst he sends none.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Just, if he send me no husband; for the which

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: evening. Lord, I could not endure a husband with a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and make him my waiting-gentlewoman? He that hath a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: beard is less than a man: and he that is more than

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a youth is not for me, and he that is less than a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: man, I am not for him: therefore, I will even take

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: sixpence in earnest of the bear-ward, and lead his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: apes into hell.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Well, then, go you into hell?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, but to the gate; and there will the devil meet

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his head, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: say 'Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: heaven; here's no place for you maids:' so deliver

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter for the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: heavens; he shows me where the bachelors sit, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: there live we as merry as the day is long.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: [To HERO]  Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: by your father.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and say 'Father, as it please you.' But yet for all

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: make another curtsy and say 'Father, as it please

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: me.'

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Not till God make men of some other metal than

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: overmastered with a pierce of valiant dust? to make

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, uncle, I'll none: Adam's sons are my brethren;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and, truly, I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Daughter, remember what I told you: if the prince

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: not wooed in good time: if the prince be too

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: important, tell him there is measure in every thing

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, Hero:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a Scotch jig,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a measure, and a cinque pace: the first suit is hot

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and hasty, like a Scotch jig, and full as

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: fantastical; the wedding, mannerly-modest, as a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: measure, full of state and ancientry; and then comes

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: repentance and, with his bad legs, falls into the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: cinque pace faster and faster, till he sink into his grave.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by daylight.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: All put on their masks

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: So you walk softly and look sweetly and say nothing,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I am yours for the walk; and especially when I walk away.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: With me in your company?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I may say so, when I please.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And when please you to say so?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: When I like your favour; for God defend the lute

speaker: HERO
text_entry: should be like the case!

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Speak low, if you speak love.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Drawing her aside

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Well, I would you did like me.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: So would not I, for your own sake; for I have many

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: ill-qualities.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Which is one?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: I say my prayers aloud.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I love you the better: the hearers may cry, Amen.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: God match me with a good dancer!

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: done! Answer, clerk.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: No more words: the clerk is answered.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: I know you well enough; you are Signior Antonio.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: At a word, I am not.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: I know you by the waggling of your head.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: You could never do him so ill-well, unless you were

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: the very man. Here's his dry hand up and down: you

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: are he, you are he.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: At a word, I am not.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? Go to,

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: mum, you are he: graces will appear, and there's an

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: end.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Will you not tell me who told you so?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: No, you shall pardon me.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Not now.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: out of the 'Hundred Merry Tales:'--well this was

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Signior Benedick that said so.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: What's he?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I am sure you know him well enough.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Not I, believe me.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Did he never make you laugh?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I pray you, what is he?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Why, he is the prince's jester: a very dull fool;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: only his gift is in devising impossible slanders:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: none but libertines delight in him; and the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: commendation is not in his wit, but in his villany;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: for he both pleases men and angers them, and then

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the fleet: I would he had boarded me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Do, do: he'll but break a comparison or two on me;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: strikes him into melancholy; and then there's a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: supper that night.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Music

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: We must follow the leaders.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In every good thing.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the next turning.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: withdrawn her father to break with him about it.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Are not you Signior Benedick?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: You know me well; I am he.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Signior, you are very near my brother in his love:

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you, dissuade him

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: do the part of an honest man in it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: How know you he loves her?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I heard him swear his affection.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: So did I too; and he swore he would marry her to-night.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Come, let us to the banquet.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Exeunt DON JOHN and BORACHIO

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: 'Tis certain so; the prince wooes for himself.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Friendship is constant in all other things

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Save in the office and affairs of love:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Let every eye negotiate for itself

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: This is an accident of hourly proof,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Re-enter BENEDICK

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Count Claudio?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yea, the same.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Come, will you go with me?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Whither?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Even to the next willow, about your own business,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: county. What fashion will you wear the garland of?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: about your neck, like an usurer's chain? or under

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You must wear

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: it one way, for the prince hath got your Hero.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I wish him joy of her.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier: so they

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: sell bullocks. But did you think the prince would

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: have served you thus?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I pray you, leave me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Ho! now you strike like the blind man: 'twas the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: boy that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If it will not be, I'll leave you.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: know me! The prince's fool! Ha? It may be I go

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: under that title because I am merry. Yea, but so I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: am apt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed: it

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: that puts the world into her person and so gives me

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: out. Well, I'll be revenged as I may.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Re-enter DON PEDRO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Now, signior, where's the count? did you see him?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: warren: I told him, and I think I told him true,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: that your grace had got the good will of this young

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: lady; and I offered him my company to a willow-tree,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: To be whipped! What's his fault?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The flat transgression of a schoolboy, who, being

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: companion, and he steals it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: transgression is in the stealer.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and the garland too; for the garland he might have

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you, who, as I take it, have stolen his birds' nest.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the owner.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you say honestly.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: gentleman that danced with her told her she is much

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: wronged by you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: O, she misused me past the endurance of a block!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: an oak but with one green leaf on it would have

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: answered her; my very visor began to assume life and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: scold with her. She told me, not thinking I had been

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: myself, that I was the prince's jester, that I was

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: duller than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting at

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: if her breath were as terrible as her terminations,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: there were no living near her; she would infect to

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the north star. I would not marry her, though she

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: were endowed with all that Adam bad left him before

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the fire too. Come, talk not of her: you shall find

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: some scholar would conjure her; for certainly, while

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose, because they

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: would go thither; so, indeed, all disquiet, horror

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and perturbation follows her.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Look, here she comes.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Will your grace command me any service to the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: world's end? I will go on the slightest errand now

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on;

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the great

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pigmies,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rather than hold three words' conference with this

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: harpy. You have no employment for me?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: None, but to desire your good company.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: O God, sir, here's a dish I love not: I cannot

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: endure my Lady Tongue.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Signior Benedick.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile; and I gave

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: him use for it, a double heart for his single one:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: marry, once before he won it of me with false dice,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: therefore your grace may well say I have lost it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: should prove the mother of fools. I have brought

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, how now, count! wherefore are you sad?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Not sad, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: How then? sick?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Neither, my lord.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: The count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: well; but civil count, civil as an orange, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: something of that jealous complexion.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: though, I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: fair Hero is won: I have broke with her father,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: and his good will obtained: name the day of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: marriage, and God give thee joy!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and an

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: grace say Amen to it.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Speak, count, 'tis your cue.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady, as

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: you and dote upon the exchange.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: ear that he is in her heart.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And so she doth, cousin.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: world but I, and I am sunburnt; I may sit in a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: corner and cry heigh-ho for a husband!

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I would rather have one of your father's getting.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you? Your

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Will you have me, lady?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, my lord, unless I might have another for

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: working-days: your grace is too costly to wear

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: every day. But, I beseech your grace, pardon me: I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: was born to speak all mirth and no matter.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: becomes you; for, out of question, you were born in

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: a merry hour.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then there

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: was a star danced, and under that was I born.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Cousins, God give you joy!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your grace's pardon.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: There's little of the melancholy element in her, my

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps, and

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: not ever sad then; for I have heard my daughter say,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: herself with laughing.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: they would talk themselves mad.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To-morrow, my lord: time goes on crutches till love

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: have all his rites.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: seven-night; and a time too brief, too, to have all

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: things answer my mind.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Hercules' labours; which is, to bring Signior

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: affection the one with the other. I would fain have

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: you three will but minister such assistance as I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: shall give you direction.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: nights' watchings.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And I, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And you too, gentle Hero?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my

speaker: HERO
text_entry: cousin to a good husband.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I know. Thus far can I praise him; he is of a noble

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: strain, of approved valour and confirmed honesty. I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: will teach you how to humour your cousin, that she

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: shall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: two helps, will so practise on Benedick that, in

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Cupid is no longer an archer: hi s glory shall be

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: ours, for we are the only love-gods. Go in with me,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: and I will tell you my drift.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt
